snippet.textDisplay: Pandora certainly is the best place to be. For the blue-skinned lizards, this is their primary and serene sanctuary filled with all kinds of different fauna and flora species. What I find incredible is the fact that this is all a product of James Cameron's vision. There's always possibilities that stretch beyond Earth and the other discoveries that we may find out there in the intergalactic space.
snippet.textOriginal: Pandora certainly is the best place to be. For the blue-skinned lizards, this is their primary and serene sanctuary filled with all kinds of different fauna and flora species. What I find incredible is the fact that this is all a product of James Cameron's vision. There's always possibilities that stretch beyond Earth and the other discoveries that we may find out there in the intergalactic space.

snippet.textDisplay:
Mr. Night shamalama ding dong made like 3 or 4 good films that I have seen. Signs was dope as hell at the time, 6th sense is a classic and the village was pretty interesting, a great premise, just not the best execution.
Edit: I might be the only person on earth who hasn't seen all of the avatar show, only a handful of episodes.
Edit: oooooh wow. Wowwwee. Now I see why everyone says this movie was so disrespectful. My lord, did they do nothing right? Lol
snippet.textOriginal:
Mr. Night shamalama ding dong made like 3 or 4 good films that I have seen. Signs was dope as hell at the time, 6th sense is a classic and the village was pretty interesting, a great premise, just not the best execution.
Edit: I might be the only person on earth who hasn't seen all of the avatar show, only a handful of episodes.
Edit: oooooh wow. Wowwwee. Now I see why everyone says this movie was so disrespectful. My lord, did they do nothing right? Lol

snippet.textDisplay: Why do you say Avatar Tradition or Avatar System?   They are born as the Avatar.   There's no point where an individual or group can choose who the Avatar is.   The Avatar ability is transferred to a new person and now go figure it out.

snippet.textDisplay:
I like how the humans have built an industry around alien whale hunting, despite it being super dangerous and expensive.  All to harvest the whales brain juice that makes up .0001% of it's body.
Meanwhile, humans have figured out how to grow Navi bodies in test tubes.  So there is literally no reason why they couldn't just use those same test tubes to grow a bunch of alien whale brains.  They could do it on an industrial scale, and harvest them all on earth, with no actual animals killed, this whole industry makes no sense.

snippet.textDisplay:
Low and behold, it‚Äôs officially 1 year old!!!

This was just as good as the first movie 
3 hours is long but James Cameron has come a long way with the motion capture technology 
The CGI looks smoother, the underwater scenes are breathtaking, and I appreciate the introduction of the Water tribe with its own philosophy 
It's all about the escape and spectacle wanting live on this world of Pandora 
A story that's predictable and not a game changer but the sheer visual majesty is utterly spectacular with the environments, the creatures, and the cinematography 
An engaging cinematic experience and most of the characters get their own proper arcs even if it‚Äôs more of the same 
Sam Worthington is better here and Zoe Saldana has the best acting next to the young daughter 
Curious how the next 4 movies will expand given Cameron wants to go further
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I have a couple of reasons for not caring for the Avatar movies. Don't get me wrong, I do like them but I think they're overrated as hell, especially the first one. The thing that bugged me the most about it was how the Na'vi oh so quickly forgave Jake's betrayal. He cucked Tsu'tey, got the clan leader killed, the big tree destroyed, and countless Na'vi were slaughtered. And all it took to get back in their good graces was him pulling up on the big bad raptor thing, I forgot its name. Even as a kid, I thought that was insane.
snippet.textOriginal: I have a couple of reasons for not caring for the Avatar movies. Don't get me wrong, I do like them but I think they're overrated as hell, especially the first one. He cucked Tsu'tey, got the clan leader killed, the big tree destroyed, and countless Na'vi were slaughtered. snippet.textDisplay: As a native kid I loved this movie and still to this day when people ask what I mean by "not religious but I believe in a higher power entertwined with balance and energy" I just say "like in avatar the blue people movie but not as obvious". It was really the only movie that was well known that kind of describes traditional native religion in a comprehensive and empathetic way. And the obvious allegory of what settlers did to natives in a non-romantic way (cough pocahontas) I could appreciate. And I think most viewers did. I think the hate comes from uncomfortable people not wanting to empathize with the pain caused by the creation of their country and the destruction of culture and our mother planet. That's the unease.
snippet.textOriginal: As a native kid I loved this movie and still to this day when people ask what I mean by "not religious but I believe in a higher power entertwined with balance and energy" I just say "like in avatar the blue people movie but not as obvious". It was really the only movie that was well known that kind of describes traditional native religion in a comprehensive and empathetic way. And the obvious allegory of what settlers did to natives in a non-romantic way (cough pocahontas) I could appreciate. And I think most viewers did. I think the hate comes from uncomfortable people not wanting to empathize with the pain caused by the creation of their country and the destruction of culture and our mother planet. snippet.textDisplay:
Let me preface this with the fact that I'm just some guy who watched the movies in 3D cinema, and enjoyed immersing myself in the world. I didn't really care about the story further than there being plotpoints leading me to eventually see more of the planet. I have no opinion on Cameron either.

Not to attack your overall analysis here, but as someone with interest in history I felt like I had to tack on to one of your points; the perfection of Navi as opposed to our ancestral civilizations.
When I see a piece of media actively advertising itself as historical in any manner, I of course get quite annoyed if some parts are knowingly glossed over, like here with your examples of human sacrifice and other raid behaviour. As far as Avatar goes though, it doesn't bother me as Navi are not portrayed as a historically accurate human society. Therefore, if Cameron is truly setting them up as the future "ideal" human civilization (which I think is just that, an ideal), wouldn't it make sense to omit the mistakes of the past when portraying the possible reformed future? I think that's also supported by them actually not being human, and avoiding the modernly problematic parts of hunter gatherer societies. If Cameron wants to show the viewer his own ideal, I'm sure it would not include taking up raids and sacrifices alongside the positives of history.

But again, I just felt compelled by this part of the video. I suppose things change depending on the perspective, but just throwing my two cents on the historical inaccuracy standalone.

Not to attack your overall analysis here, but as someone with interest in history I felt like I had to tack on to one of your points; the perfection of Navi as opposed to our ancestral civilizations.
When I see a piece of media actively advertising itself as historical in any manner, I of course get quite annoyed if some parts are knowingly glossed over, like here with your examples of human sacrifice and other raid behaviour. As far as Avatar goes though, it doesn't bother me as Navi are not portrayed as a historically accurate human society. Therefore, if Cameron is truly setting them up as the future "ideal" human civilization (which I think is just that, an ideal), wouldn't it make sense to omit the mistakes of the past when portraying the possible reformed future? I think that's also supported by them actually not being human, and avoiding the modernly problematic parts of hunter gatherer societies. But again, I just felt compelled by this part of the video. I suppose things change depending on the perspective, but just throwing my two cents on the historical inaccuracy standalone.

snippet.textDisplay:
Also the reason why so few people want to play paladins in epic fantasy games (D&D) but everyone will at some point gravitate to playing thieves. Being too "good" is boring.

Game of Thrones solved this by making every character have some sort of negative trait. 

Jamie Lannister was a younger good looking guy from a rich noble family who was very good with a sword and honor bound as a knight to protect the king, women, the weak, the innocent. The perfect paladin.

But he was also overconfident, impulsive, and nailing his sister the queen. Not to mention had a reputation as a king killer.

GoT characters are never 100% evil or good. This is on purpose. It makes them believable. 

Avatar on the other hand misses the "real society" aspect and portrays them 100% as good natured victims. No one buys that for a moment. Which is why the movies fail.
snippet.textOriginal:
Also the reason why so few people want to play paladins in epic fantasy games (D&D) but everyone will at some point gravitate to playing thieves. Being too "good" is boring.

Game of Thrones solved this by making every character have some sort of negative trait. 

Jamie Lannister was a younger good looking guy from a rich noble family who was very good with a sword and honor bound as a knight to protect the king, women, the weak, the innocent. The perfect paladin.

But he was also overconfident, impulsive, and nailing his sister the queen. Not to mention had a reputation as a king killer.

GoT characters are never 100% evil or good. This is on purpose. It makes them believable. 

Avatar on the other hand misses the "real society" aspect and portrays them 100% as good natured victims. No one buys that for a moment. Which is why the movies fail.

snippet.textDisplay: I love avatar for it's beautifully constructed fauna and flora and its colorful world, not its cheap political commentary or even its characters. The whole humans vs aliens aspect is honestly the only boring part of the films.
snippet.textOriginal: I love avatar for it's beautifully constructed fauna and flora and its colorful world, not its cheap political commentary or even its characters. The whole humans vs aliens aspect is honestly the only boring part of the films.

snippet.textDisplay: so much better writing would have had the RDA making use of at minimum modern lateral methods, navi trees siting on top of the mineral we want, bore machine goes whir, locals have no idea they're down there unless the ceiling of the mine gives in. the RDA gets straw manned so hard they're actively sabotaging themselves even from a profit angle. the damn moon has a global synaptic network, any competent corporation as soon as they understand what grace has identified is going to full stop what they're doing because that smells an awful lot like money. modern mining multi mines (when a nickel mine pulls out a ton of nickel ore and finds its chalk full of copper they dont stuff it back in the hole , they send it off and add it to the profit margin.) low profile mines, and works out how they're going to buff out the dent. the RDA should be operating a modern first world method at minimum. the RDA is also spending an exorbitant amount of money on security they really shouldn't need. why are they running a bucket line pit mine when the location encourages shaft mining they could theoretically pressurize and definitely better defend. the whales have a weird super chemical, why is this not the target of a hard core synthesize effort? they could have had the home tree fall over because the RDA accidentally drilled through a tap root for home tree and caused a cave in. or had the rda constantly following the whales around trying to figure out what the foundational diet/nutrients the whale things are eating to create the chemical and the navi conflict is the RDA's complete lack of chill or understanding where they're blundering through sacred sites
snippet.textOriginal: so much better writing would have had the RDA making use of at minimum modern lateral methods, navi trees siting on top of the mineral we want, bore machine goes whir, locals have no idea they're down there unless the ceiling of the mine gives in. the RDA gets straw manned so hard they're actively sabotaging themselves even from a profit angle. the damn moon has a global synaptic network, any competent corporation as soon as they understand what grace has identified is going to full stop what they're doing because that smells an awful lot like money. modern mining multi mines (when a nickel mine pulls out a ton of nickel ore and finds its chalk full of copper they dont stuff it back in the hole , they send it off and add it to the profit margin.) low profile mines, and works out how they're going to buff out the dent. the RDA should be operating a modern first world method at minimum. the RDA is also spending an exorbitant amount of money on security they really shouldn't need. why are they running a bucket line pit mine when the location encourages shaft mining they could theoretically pressurize and definitely better defend. the whales have a weird super chemical, why is this not the target of a hard core synthesize effort? they could have had the home tree fall over because the RDA accidentally drilled through a tap root for home tree and caused a cave in. or had the rda constantly following the whales around trying to figure out what the foundational diet/nutrients the whale things are eating to create the chemical and the navi conflict is the RDA's complete lack of chill or understanding where they're blundering through sacred sites

snippet.textDisplay:
Well these criticisms might be pre-mature because it seems like this is where the story is going. From my understanding, there are 3 more sequels planned and Cameron said he will explore the dark side of the Navi in the 3rd. 

Additionally, we see in the second one Neytiri has a strong hatred for humans: she becomes a bigot, even willing to kill an innocent kid because he is human. Unsurprisingly, she is the most (the only) interesting character in the franchise by far
